reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s Section 2.4 “value as product of factors” model and the associated ‘one flaw can unwind most value’ fragility mechanism. That is a meaningful support for the paper’s intuitive case against “easy eutopia,” but it is not the whole argument (the later Section 3 taxonomy of bounded/unbounded value functions and fussiness does a lot of independent work). So centrality is moderate. The critique makes a real point that a multiplicative model builds in strong complementarity/non-compensability and that changing aggregation toward substitutability (additive/portfolio) would reduce right-skew and enlarge the set of “mostly-great” futures; however, it overstates how much pluralism/moral uncertainty tends to imply substitutability (it can also imply needing to do well on many axes to satisfy multiple views), and it somewhat exaggerates that this is “not patchable,” since the paper already presents the product model as a toy/illustrative model and could defend fragility via other distributions/structures. Most claims are broadly plausible, but some (e.g., maximin/leximin supporting “rescue by a few decisive axes”) are dubious, and the modal claim about what pluralism “pushes toward” is contestable. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: "Critique questions whether moral values are complementary"
